div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Late Northern news.
div3.p:
From Northern dates of the 6th, which have been partly anticipated by telegraph, we make up a summary of the news.
In the Yankee Congress, on the 5th, a resolution declaring Grant's order expelling the Jews from his department tyrannical, usurping, and unjust and requesting the President to countermand the same, was introduced by Mr. Powell, and laid over.

div4.head: The arbitrary arrests of Lincoln — the Abolitionists Backing down.
div4.p:
The frequent complaints made in the United States Senate about illegal arrests by Lincoln's minions for treason have had their effect.
The Abolition Senators at first treated them with contempt, but have been forced to treat them with more "distinguished consideration. "--Mr. Shannon, of Ohio, in addressing the Senate last week on the subject, said:

q.p:
Mr. President, this Senate will not consider a graver question than this.
It will not consider a question that is more fixed on the public mind than this.
I believe that a great deal of undue clamor has been made by particular against the Administration on the ground of these arrests; but if it has been so, it has been because of the manner of these arrests, and the manner in which the men arrested have been discharged, the failure to give them an examination, and to make public the causes of the arrests.
These are the reasons why the clamor has been made.
I know that in the canvass in our own State, and gentlemen from Indiana and Pennsylvania and New York say to me that these arrests, sometimes made in secret for frivolous and unimportant matter, sometimes for foolish and bad language, sometimes for good cause, have been made the occasion of eloquent declamation.

div4.p:
Every person who has heard the story of these pretended wrongs has sympathized with probably a guilty man, simply because that guilty man has not had a chance of a fair trial before some tribunal, or because the facts which led to his arrest have not been made public.
I do not care who desires an inquiry if a Senator will in his place say that one of his constituents has been deprived of his liberty, and that he believes he has been unjustly deprived of that liberty, that he desires to know the cause why he is detained in a military prison, we are bound to give him that information.
If you do not do it, what will be the consequence?
You may be the cause of an injustice without a remedy, and without any limit of duration except life itself.
We know very well that they cannot appeal to the Courts, because the very attempt to appeal to the Courts might create an armed controversy between State and National authority.

In the future the danger is still more imminent than it has been in the past.
In the past in the fresh enthusiasm of the people, in their real and earnestness to sustain the Administration and to prosecute the war, they have probably allowed a great many things to pass unnoticed that they will not in the future.
Hereafter you will have men to call you to strict account for every act even of lawful seizure.--Let us be prepared to defend every act with full information given to us in an official form, so that when any Senator here says, "My constituent has been arrested and held unlawfully in your military prison," you can turn him to the record and say, "That citizen fired upon the flag of his country; that citizen openly prevented the enlistment of volunteers to defend, that flag, that citizen committed this or that crime."

And, sir, when we are able thus to defend the Administration for every arrest made by if we can go before the people of our country and demand their sympathy, their aid, their support, in the prosecution of the war; but if we waste the enthusiasm of our people, and allow these side issues to lead us off into col- unlawful force, we take from ourselves strength that we want to use against the common enemy.
Every thing that tends to divide us, to distract us, to divide our people into parties and classes, to excite sympathy against the Government, or anger against the Government, whether well or ill-founded, weakens us, and thus deprives us of strength which it is necessary for us to use in order to put down this rebellion.

div4.head: Official Dispatches from Rosecrans.
div4.p:
Two official dispatches from Rosecrans are published in the Northern papers.
The first, dated on the 3d, "in front of Murfreesboro'," says:

q.p:
Our left and centre met with a strong resistance such as the nature of the country permits, the rolling or hilly routes, skirted by cedar thickets and farms, and intersected by small streams, with rocky, bluff banks, forming serious obstacles.
Gen. McCook drove Gen. Hardee's corps a mile and a half from Nolensville, and occupied the place.
Gen. Crittenden reached within a mile and a half of Lavergne.
Gen. Thomas reached the Wilson pike, meeting with no serious opposition.

div4.p:
On the 27th Gen. McCook drove Gen. Hardee from Nolensville and pushed forward a reconnoitering division six miles towards Shelbyville, and found that Gen. Hardee had retreated towards Murfreesboro'. Gen. Crittenden fought and drove the enemy before him, occupying the line of Stewart's creek, and capturing some prisoners with slight loss.--Gen. Thomas occupied the vicinity of Nolensville, when he was partially surprised, thrown into confusion, and driven back.
Gen. Sheridan's division had repulsed the enemy four times, and protected the flank of the centre which not only held its own, but advanced until this untoward event, which compelled me to retain the left wing to support the right until it should be rallied and assume a new position.
On the 1st instant the rebels opened by an attack on us, and were again repulsed.

On the 2d instant there was skirmishing along the front with threats of an attack until about three o'clock in the afternoon, when the enemy advanced, throwing a small division across Stone's river to occupy the commanding ground there.

While reconnoitering the ground occupied by this division, which had no artillery, I saw a heavy force emerging from the woods and advancing in line of battle three lines deep. --They drove our little division before them after a sharp contest; in which we lost 70 or 80 killed, and 375 wounded, but they were finally repulsed by Gen. Negley's division and the remaining troops of the left wing of General Merton's Pioneer Brigade, and fled far over the field and beyond their entrenchments, their officers rallying them with great difficulty.
He lost heavily.
We occupied the ground with the left wing last night.
The lines were completed at 4 o'clock in the morning.

The 3d was spent in bringing up and distributing provisions and ammunition.
It has been raining all day. The ground is very heavy.

opener.salute: To Major-General H. W. Halleck, General-in-Chief:

div4.p:
Following my dispatch of last evening, I have to announce that the enemy are in full retreat.
They left last night.

The rain having raised the river, and the bridge across it between the left wing and centre being incomplete, I deemed it prudent to withdraw that wing during the night.
This occupied my time until four o'clock, and fatigued the troops.

The announcement of the retreat was known to me at seven o'clock this morning.
Our ammunition train arrived during the night.
To-day was occupied in distributing ammunition, burying the dead, and collecting arms from the field of battle.

The pursuit was commenced by the centre, the two leading brigades arriving at the west side of Stone's river this evening.
The railroad bridge was saved, but in what condition is not known.
We shall occupy the town and push the pursuit to-morrow.
Our Medical Director estimates the wounded in hospitals at 5,500, and our dead at 1,000.

We have to deplore the loss of Lieut. Col. Gereache, whose capacity and general deportment had already endeared him to all the officers of this command, and whose gallantry on the field of battle excited their admiration.

div4.head: The Legislature of New York--a denunciation of Gov. Seymour.
div4.p:
The Legislature of the State of New York assembled at Albany on the 6th inst. The fact that the Governor just inaugurated was elected in opposition to the radical and imbecile administration at Washington, in connection with the fact that the conservative and radical factions are so nearly equally divided, has caused more than ordinary interest to be felt in Gotham in regard to the doings at Albany.
The conservative party have a working majority in the Assembly, and it was thought would be able to secure the organization of that branch of the Legislature, without the assistance of the Union Democrat.--The Governor will, beyond doubt, have this branch of the Legislature to co-operate with him.

The sixty-five conservative votes in the Assembly secure to that party a working majority, and render them responsible for the action taken on all measures submitted to them.
It likewise gives them full power to prevent the election of United States Senator this winter, if they see fit to do so. The Senate is largely Republican, thus being in a position to counteract the decisions of the Assembly, and effectually block the plans of the Governor and defeat the measures of the conservative House.
There may, however, be a change in this majority before many weeks of the session roll away.
The Washington Chronicle (Forney's organ,) in a bitter denunciation of Governor Seymour's inaugural address and his proposed removal of the New York Police Commissioners, closes as follows:

q.p:
"We congratulate the hundred thousand patriotic voters of the Empire State, who were so anxious to exchange a man like Edwin D. Morgan for this new incumbent, on their choice, and wish them joy of their bargain.
We hope the thousands of voters who were wheedled, by the honeyed words of the eloquent Prince, into the belief that they were voting for the vigorous prosecution of the war, will admire their new Governor's novel idea of protecting 'sneaks' and encouraging traitors.
We trust the merchants of New York city will enjoy the renewal of their acquaintance with their 'loved and lost' Southern customers.
Will the one hundred and fifty thousand patriots, or such of them as still remain alive, who went out to fight the battles of their country, approve the attempts of Gov. Seymour to make all their hardships, wounds, and sickness, so many bitter and unavailing sacrifices, and the deaths of their comrades so much wasted blood?
Do they enjoy the prospect of returning to their homes and living under the rule of an ally of the merciless foes they have been fighting to subdue?"

"The exact practical results of this manœuvre of Governor Seymour's we cannot, of course, foretell, but of his intentions there can be no doubt.
We are glad that he has indicated them so unequivocally, and that, instead of concealing his ultimate purposes, as he did before his election, by lurking behind platitudes and deceptions, he has determined upon a bold and practical opposition to the efforts of the Government to put down the rebellion."

div4.head: The London times on Reconstruction.
div4.p: The London Times, of the 19th, in an article on the position of affairs in America, says:

q.p:
So far as we in England can gain any knowledge of what is passing in the jealously guarded councils of the Confederate States, there is no reason to believe that the South has faltered in its purpose of obtaining absolute independence.
The latest advices from Richmond represent all classes to be as fierce in spirit and as confident as ever.
The Government at Washington was sending recruits to all its armies as fast as desertions, want of money, and want of arms would allow it. On both sides there seems to be all the hatred and all the determination which prevailed a year ago. Yet amid all this, there has undoubtedly arisen in New York and other cities of the North a vague idea — what some people would call a presentiment — that the work of destruction is about to be brought to a close.--Since the victories of the Democrats throughout the Federal States have given proof that the and conduct of party are condemned by a majority of the North, visions of a reconstructed republic are becoming more frequent and clear to the Democratic politicians.

div4.p:
Like all Americans, except a very few, he would rather belong to a great and powerful country capable of dictating to the world, but with the sin of slavery clinging to it, than to a purified territory which should be less extensive and formidable.
So even Mr. Lincoln seems ready to adopt the Democratic "platform" and to coax back the South.
A scheme for permissive emancipation nearly forty years hence is but the tribute which must be paid by decency to the principles which are to be practically laid aside.
How far these blandishments will have any success with the Confederates we cannot tell.
We do not believe they will prevail; we do not believe it will ever be possible to restore the Union; but whether the two incensed communities compose their differences or separate peaceably, the result will be gratifying to England, which has interfered in the quarrel in no way, except to urge on the North the impolicy and wickedness of a war of subjugation.
In spite, then, of the menaces they direct against us, we can assure the Northern people that we wish them all success in any plan of conciliation.
It is certainly strange that, while querulously complaining of the want of sympathy for their cause which exists in England, their conversation, their speeches, and their political writings are full of a rancor against us which would make a more susceptible nation than our own ready to take the first opportunity of revenge.
But we are so little affected by this never-failing stream of detraction and menace that we can afford to congratulate them on the better spirit which they seem to be now displaying toward their alienated brethren; and from the liberality which a part of the American public has shown in its subscription for the relief of Lancashire distress, we are willing to believe that a clearer perception of the honorable part which England has played during the war now prevails.

div4.head: Beecher in Peril.
div4.p:
As the cars en route to New York stopped at Elizabeth, N. J., on the evening of the 5th, the passengers noticed an unusual commotion among the citizens, who were assembled in large numbers in the vicinity of the railroad station.
Upon inquiry it was ascertained that the indignation of the people had been aroused in consequence of a report having been circulated that Henry Ward Beecher had arrived, and was to preach one of his characteristic sermons in the goodly city of Elizabeth.
The crowd manifested the most hostile intentions towards Beecher, whom they were looking up in all directions.
That gentleman, however, managed to elude this very unpleasant vigilance, and having secured the services of a posse of policemen, he was stealthily conveyed to the cars and rolled back to New York without preaching his sermon.

div3.head: A tribute to a Brave soldier.
div3.p: --Gen. Lee has written the following letter to Gov. Pickens, of South Carolina:

opener.salute:
To His Excellency F. W. Pickens, Governor of South Carolina:
Sir

div4.p: --While South Carolina is mourning the loss of her gallant and distinguished son, Gen. Maxcy Gregg, permit me to join in your sorrow for his death.
From my first acquaintance, when you sent him with his gallant regiment to the defence of our frontier in Virginia, I have admired his disinterested patriotism and his unselfish devotion.

He has always been at the post of duty and of danger, and his services in this army have been of inestimable value, and his loss is deeply lamented.
In its greatest triumphs and its bloodiest battles he has borne a distinguished part.
On the Chickahominy, on the plains of Manassas, at Harper's Ferry, Sharpsburg, and Shepherdstown, he led his brigade with distinguished skill and dauntless valor.

On the wooded heights of Fredericksburg he fell in front of his brigade in close conflict with the advancing foe. The death of such a man is a costly sacrifice, for it is to men of his high integrity and commanding intellect that the country must look to give character to her councils, that she may be respected and honored by all nations.
Among those of his State who will proudly read the history of his deeds, may many be found to imitate his noble example.

closer.salute: I have the honor to be, with great respect, your obedient serv't,

div3.head: The iron navies of France and England.
div3.p:
Mr. Donald McKay, the Yankee ship builder of Boston, has been engaged for some months past in visiting the European navy yards, and he contributes the results of his observations to the Boston Commercial Bulletin.
The information which he gives concerning the iron vessels of the French and English navies is interesting and valuable.

Writing from Paris, Mr. McKay describes the progress of the iron-clad war vessels of the two nations, and shows what are the advantages of France over England.
In addition to ten iron-clad floating batteries, constructed during and shortly after the Crimean war, France has also constructed four iron frigates of the Glaire class, (the Glaire, Normandie, Invincible, and Conronne,) two floating batteries, (the Peiho and Saigon,) and two iron rams, (Solferino and Magenta,) and has on the stocks nine more floating batteries and ten iron frigates.
It is in contemplation to finish all these vessels in five years, but in case of necessity they could be completed in one year.
The English have completed only four iron-clad frigates, (the Warrior, Black Prince, Defence, and Resistance,) but are building the Achilles, Hecton, Valiant, Aginesurt, Minotaur, Northumberland, Prince Albert, (all iron ships,) and the wooden ships Prince Consort, Ocean, Caledonia, Royal Oak, and Royal Alfred--all of which are now casing with iron.
The summing up is as follows, in Mr. McKay's own words:

q.p: "The French can have by the end of the year a fleet of sixteen iron-cased frigates fit for foreign service, and the English can muster in a year and a half sixteen iron-cased frigates and two iron cased corvettes, all fit for foreign service and for an aggressive warfare."

div3.p: Some of the peculiarities of the French iron navy are thus noted by Mr. McKay:

q.p:
"The iron-cased ram-ships Solferino and Magenta, of fifty-two guns and 1,000 horse-power, are built of timber.
The iron-casing up to the main deck extends from stem to stern, but the two batteries are only cased amidships, covering thirteen guns, in each battery, or each deck.
The batteries are continued (outside of an iron-cased bulkhead) to stem and stern, similar to the Warrior, and left to destruction in case of a light.
The stem inclines from the load-line upwards in a graceful hollow line backwards, and is on the upper part ornamented with an eagle.
About three feet below the load line, attached to the stem and fore-part of the vessel, is a heavy wrought iron spar of sixteen tons weight for running down other vessels.

"The new iron-cased frigates are on a similar plan to the Glaire, but with a little greater length and more height of battery.
While the Glaire and her sister ships have only six feet height of battery, the new frigates will have their ports seven and a quarter feet above the water.
Nine of these frigates, viz: the Provence, Savoie, Revanche, Flandreau, Gauloise, Magnamine, Valeurense, Surveillant, and Guyenne, are built of timber; only one, the Heroine, is building of iron at L'Orient.

"Two iron-cased floating batteries, Paixhan and Palestro, are of fourteen guns and one hundred and fifty horse power, built of timber.
They have no rudder, and will be steered by large fins or leeboards, experience having shown that the common rudders are entirely insufficient for steering these ships."

div3.p: New improvements in the English iron ships are described as follows:

q.p:
"There are two other classes of ships building on plans of Mr. Reed, naval architect, who got a temporary appointment in the navy.
The characteristics of these ships are that they are only plated a little above and below the loadline and the midship part of the vessel containing the guns.
The object of the design is to relieve the ends of his vessel of weight.
The plan has found great favor with the Admiralty, and a great number of 36 gun frigates are to be transformed into iron cased sloops on this plan.

"A small vessel on this plan, the Enterprise, is building at Deptford dockyard.
She has a length of 180 feet, breadth of 36 feet, and draught of water of 15 feet. Her engines will be of 160 horse-power, and her speed is estimated at 9.50 knots.
She will carry an armament of four Armstrong 100-pounders."

div3.p:
Mr. McKay draws unfavorable deductions from a comparison of these French and English ships with the class of U. S. Monitors, contending that the latter cannot live in a sea way, and that a heavy frigate would run them down.
He says:

q.p:
"If we compare with these immense fleets the iron-cased navy of the United States impartially, we have to acknowledge that in case of a war with either of the above powers, we would have to keep entirely on the defensive, to submit to a disgraceful blockade, and to leave our merchant ships all over the globe to the mercy of our enemy.
All the Monitors, which we are building by the dozen, are very well to defend our harbors, but they are entirely unfit to break a blockade or to act on the high seas, for to say that these vessels are good sea boats, or suitable for men to live in, is simply ridiculous, in which statement I will be upheld by all experienced sailors and shipbuilders of any note.

"With their very light draught of water these Monitors never can obtain a high degree of speed, and if ever they should fall in with any of the large frigates in deep water they will be terribly handled, and in all probability run down.
Do not think that this could not be done because the Merrimac failed in her attempt to run down the Monitor.
She struck with a speed of three or four knots, or even not as much as that; but a mass of six to nine thousand tons in weight, driven at a speed of twelve to fourteen knots, would give a different result.

"Of all the iron-cased ships which we have, the only one that might successfully cope with the large English frigates is the Ironsides, built in Philadelphia.
She is well planned, and her practical construction very well executed; but her speed is too low to use the good points of the vessel to advantage, and the way of fastening her plates will not stand the test of a heavy cannonade; for in the experiments made in England with armor plates, similarly fastened by screw bolts screwed in from the inside, the bolts broke off short on the inside of the plate whenever a heavy shot struck the plate near such bolts.

"It is satisfactory to know that Mr. Webb has got a contract for building an iron-cased ship according to his own plans.
He certainly will produce something able to compete with any European frigate."

div3.p: In conclusion, Mr. McKay suggests the construction for the United States Navy of twenty to thirty fast, iron-cased, shell-proof corvettes, of about ten to twelve heavy guns each, and of a moderate draught of water, with high speed; and about twenty to thirty fifty-gun frigates, not cased, for foreign service, and as many sloops, of fourteen to twenty-four guns of the highest speed obtainable, so that they may be enabled to strike unexpected blows and to evade their iron-cased adversaries, which never will obtain the same high speed at sea as can be given to them.

div3.head: A hero on crutches.
div3.p:
A paragraph has been going the rounds about a "cavalryman on crutches" in Gen. Lee's army.
The Mobile Advertiser gives the following history of this "unknown hero:"

q.p:
This soldier is Lamar Fontaine, a private in the Campbell Rangers, 2d Regiment Virginia Cavalry.
He is the eldest son of the Rev. Edward Fontaine, an Episcopal minister, residing near Jackson, Miss., who commanded the Burt Rifles, of the 18th Regiment Mississippi Volunteers, in the first battle of Manassas, and who is honorably mentioned in Gen. Beauregard's report of it. He was born in Washington county, Texas, in 1841, while his parents resided there.
Previous to the present revolution Lamar Fontaine lived in his native State, was educated in Austin and at the Military Academy in Bastrop, and learned practically the most essential duties of a soldier as a Texan Ranger and hunter on the frontiers of Western Texas, where he was unsurpassed as a dexterous rider and skillful marksman.
As soon as the war commenced he came to Mississippi and enlisted as a private in the first company organized for the defence of the State, the Mississippi Rifles, of Jackson, commanded by Capt. Robert Smith, the heroic Col. Smith, who fell at Mumfordsville, Ky. Under this officer he served at Pensacola, as an infantry soldier, and then as an artillerist until he was transferred to his father's company in the Army of the Potomac.
At the battle of Manassas he was severely wounded by a cannon-shot, which passed under his feet, bruising one of them so badly that he was unfitted for further duty as an infantry soldier.
Finding that he was unwilling to be discharged, his father procured him a transfer to Capt. Alexander's company (I) 2d Regiment Virginia Cavalry.
Under Generals Jackson and Ewell he distinguished himself in the battles of Front Royal, Cross Kevs, and all the actions of the Valley.
Near Winchester, in company with a young gentleman from Campbell county, Va., (private John Moon,) he performed a feat without a parallel in the annals of war, and which is mentioned with the highest commendation in General Ewell's official report.
These two young men, unassisted and alone, charged a piece of artillery planted on the Winchester turnpike, manned by eight of the enemy, killed and wounded two of their number, drove the rest from the gun, and brought it off in triumph to their commander.
Near Strasburg a shell exploded against his horse's head, blowing it to stomps and breaking Lamar's thigh.
While his comrades were carrying him from the field another shell wounded him severely in the hip. Soon after his wounds were dressed while lying under a tree, a Minnie ball the his neck, passed down near his spine, and badged where the surgeons have not been able to find it. Since then his right leg and side have remained paralyzed.
He recovered sufficiently to obtain leave of absence from the hospital in Charlottesville for several weeks, which he spent with his company in performing military duty with his crutches tied to his saddle.
In this condition he fought seven battles — Hazel River Bridge, Warrenton Springs, the Tappahannock or Waterloo Bridge, the battles of the 29th, 30th, and 31st of Manassas, and the battle of Germantown.

div3.p:
While the enemy were shelling Warrenton Springs, Gen. R. H. Anderson wished to ascertain what division of the army occupied the north bank of the Rappahannock opposite his position.
He volunteered to bring him the necessary information, swam the Rappahannock, surprised three of the enemy's armed pickets, and brought them across the river to the General, who gave the crutched hero a certificate complimenting his skill and gallantry.
At the battle of Hazel river a Minnie ball broke one of his crutches, and one of the enemy's horses, without a rider, ran against him and broke the other.
In the second day's fight at Manassas he had a horse killed under him, and another the day after, at the battle of Germantown.
While pursuing the enemy's cavalry a pistol shot penetrated his cap, grazed his temple, and knocked him from his horse.
Since he has been pronounced incompetent to perform military duty, on account of his wounds, and while acting as a volunteer on hospital furloughs, he has captured six prisoners, without any assistance, and killed many of the enemy.
In different battles he has had six horses killed under him.

div3.head: Stonewall Stories.
div3.p:
--A book might easily be made of the anecdotes in the papers about Stonewall Jackson.
Here is the latest, and refers to the fight at Fredericksburg:

q.p:
The night after the battle a council of war was held by Gen. Lee, to which all of his Generals of division were invited.
Gen. Jackson slept throughout the proceedings, and upon being waked and asked for his opinion, curtly said, "Drive 'em in the river, drive 'em in the river!"

div3.head: Yankee Tyranny in Norfolk.
div3.p: --The following is an extract from a letter received from a lady in Portsmouth:

q.p:
"Gen. Vicle's lady is going to govern us as well as her husband.
She was coming over on the boat from Norfolk in a carriage on the 27th., and Mrs. Mercer and some other ladies were in the cabin, and Mrs. Gen. Vicle thought that Mrs. Mercer was laughing at her, and so she ordered the guards to arrest her"

div3.p: Thus it is that our women are tyrannized over by even the wives — mistresses for all we know — of Yankee Generals.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 9, page 2.

div3.head: The Administration.
div3.p: "The President alluded very briefly to the falsehoods which had been circulated relative to the Administration, which he could not disprove, because such disapproval would give the enemy a knowledge of things which the good of the cause required to be concealed from him. That he committed some errors he did not doubt, though they were never the result of improper motives."

We copy the above from a report of the speech of President Davis to the Mississippi Legislature at Jackson, published in this paper a few days ago. It seems to us that this reply of the President ought to be satisfactory to the country.
Every reasonable man must see that the public interests might be dangerously compromised if the Government should undertake to set forth the reasons of its action in every case where the public does not know, and, from its want of knowledge, does not approve the course of the authorities.
How was it possible, for example, for that poorness soldier and gentleman, Gen. Albert Sidney Johnston, to be defended against the storm of obloquy which was raised upon his head without exposing our own weakness at a moment when the exposure would have been rain?

Faith is necessary in all human affairs, and in none more than those of a weak and struggling country.
The agents to whom it has itself confined the conduct of its Government deserve a generous confidence.
We cannot expect to understand the ground of their action always, for we have not the information by which their conduct is directed.
That they may off sometimes is simply to acknowledge that they are human and not infallible.
But that error is the rule in the Southern Administration, instead of the exception and that it errs from design or improper motives, no ere will pretend.
For ourselves, we are no partizan of any Government or any party, but we believe that President Davis is as well qualified for his responsible position as any man in the Southern Confederacy, and that he has as much interest as any other in exerting his best abilities and judgment in the performance of his public duties.
The failure of this struggle would not only involve him in the common ruin of independence and property, but bring down upon his head a doom which the great mass of the Southern people have no reason to expect.
How absurd, then, to imagine that he is not doing the best he can for the cause.
The same confidence may be justly extended to our Generals and soldiers in the field.
We must not expect impossibilities of them.
We are outnumbered by our enemies four to one, and without the men or the means to meet them at many of the points at which we are assailed.
All we can expect is that they should do the best they can with the limited means at their disposal.
And surely the annals of history furnish no example of achievements like those of the Southern soldiers against the odds they have had to encounter.
For the sake of our common cause, let us not add to our weakness by dissensions among ourselves.
Let us postpone till the end of this great quarrel every note of internal bickering, and know no enemies but the enemies of our country.

div3.head: Unaccountable Infatuation.
div3.p:
Hon. James Brooks, editor of the New York Express and one of the members elect to the next Yankee Congress, offered to an immense meeting of the Democracy, assembled in Broadway, New York, on the 30th ultimo, a series of resolutions having for their object the restoration of the Union upon its ancient basis.
The State of New Jersey is requested to interpose, through her State Government, to arrest the "existing civil war." The non-slaveholding States and the "loyal" slaveholding States are to meet in Convention at Louisville on a certain day (not named) in February.
Permission is to be asked of Old Abe Lincoln to send Commissioners to Virginia, North and South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Florida, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, Tennessee, and Texas, to invite them also to meet in like national convention.--The said Abe is to be further requested by the State Government of New Jersey to declare an armistice with or for such States as may accept this call for a national convention.
A committee is to wait on the Governor and Legislature of New Jersey, and urge them, by the Revolutionary fame of their State, to take the lead in thus laying the foundation of a national convention.

Mr. Brooks appears to be in earnest in these extravagant propositions, strange as it may appear to any man who has possession of his senses; for, upon the occasion of presenting them, he made a long speech, and expressed himself confident of their success.
Are the Northern people all natural born fools, or are they only stricken with that judicial madness which we are told the gods always inflict upon the victims of their wrath preparatory to their ruin?
Can they suppose that the South is as gailess and as lily livered as themselves, and that they are willing for mere considerations of interest to forget the unheard of outrages under which they have suffered during this war?
Can they believe them capable of so soon burying in oblivion all that they have done, and all that they have suffered?
Do they think that they no longer remember their slaughtered sons, their desolated fields, their burning towns?
Is the reign of Butler a thing to be so soon forgotten?
And are we to be invited while the smoke is still ascending from our towns — while our fields lie untilled from the abduction of our slaves — while the blood of our citizens murdered in cold blood is yet crying to Heaven for vengeance — to clasp the red hands of the assassins, and call them brothers?
The man must be permanently and hopelessly mad who can for a moment imagine it. Mr. Brooks tells his friends that some European monarchy will take advantage of the lassitude consequent upon the powerful exertions both sections are making, and conquer them both.
In return, we assure him that the people of these Confederate States would infinitely prefer being the vassals of France or England--nay, they would prefer being serfs of Russia — to becoming in any manner whatever associated, politically or otherwise, with the Yankee States.
To any other date than that they are prepared to submit, if it should please God so to order it. But to a re-union with the vile brood that is seeking their destruction they will never submit on any terms which it is possible for the ingenuity of man to devise, or even to imagine.
If the whole Yankee race should fall down in the dust tomorrow and pray us to be their masters, we would spurn them even as slaves.
Our only wish is to be separated from them finally and forever — never to see that face of one of them again — never to hear the voice of another Yankee on the South side of the Potomac or the North--to have no traffic and no intercourse of any description whatever with them.
We are fighting for separation, and we will have it, if it cost the life of every man in the Confederate States.

We are aware that many persons believe that the party of which Brooks and Van Buren are representatives desire and design to restore peace, and that at present they dare not speak out their real sentiments, which are in favor of separation.
We do not believe they are in favor of any such thing.
They would like peace on condition of our return to the Union, and they are fools enough to believe that a majority of the people in the Confederacy are in favor of re-union.
They would like peace on these terms because it would restore the commercial supremacy of the North, and especially of the city of New York, which is gone forever if the Union be not restored.
But they are as bitterly opposed to separation as Lincoln himself, or any of the thieves and murderers who lead his armies.
In the event of a refusal to return to the Union they would, to a man, unite in hounding on the assassins who are desolating our country and murdering our people as fiercely as they have ever been hounded on by Beecher and Hala.
They look only to their pockets when they preach of reconciliation and restoration.
If the same object could be effected by entirely destroying the people of the Southern States, and they thought it as easy to do, they would recommend it as the best of all possible podey.
Let them be satisfied however, President Davis expressed the sentiment of the entire Confederacy, in his speech the other night, when he said the people would sooner unite with a nation of byonas then with the detestable and detected Yankee nation anything but that.
English , French , Russian seridom, all are preferable to say association with the Yankees.

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p: --The proprietors of this with to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of

div3.head: The Yankee Raid on the White House.
div3.p:
About 500 U.S. cavalry, and a like number of infantry, landed at West Point at 12 o'clock Wednesday night. The cavalry came to the White House. Ten crossed the river, burnt the depot two stoops, about 1,000 bushels of grain, one old Yankee barge, two pontoons, set fire to the little steamer, which soon sank, but will be raised to morrow.
She is about one horse power. They also burnt Mr. Taylor's shanty, with a quantity of goods and some liquor; a house of Gen. Lee's, occupied by Captain Kimble as an eating-house; set fire to the wharf, which was soon put out by Mr. Taylor; stole several articles; waited (hid behind the bank) for the cars to arrive, which they would also have taken but for Galba Valden, engineer of the little steamer, and Capt. Gage, who went up the railroad, met the cars, and stopped them about three miles of the White House, thus serving the engine we had taken from the Yankees, and cars, worth about $25,000. They had three pieces of artillery with them, but did not use them, only firing their small arms.

Two gunboats and one came up the Pamunkey within about four miles of the White House, the same night, and returned next morning, firing as they went down.
One shell fell in the New Kent Court-House yard, bursted, and knocked out part of brick in the clerk's office.
Several others fell near.
The Court House is about two miles from the river.

A shell also fell near Captain Sparrow's house.
The gunboats had two masts each, and carried six guns on a side; the lug had one gun. The Yankees--gunboats, cavalry, and infantry — all left West Point last night at twelve o'clock. In passing through King William county they stole all Mr. William Johnson's , carried off one of his men, and made all it a darkles they met go with them.
Several made out to get away from them as West Point, and is turned to their masters.
The whole of the troops nearly wore drunk, also the slaves would not have a gotten away.
They stole several geese from William New, at the Point, the gallant officer killing two at a lick with his sword.
And now, strange to say, we had no pickets, on the Parounked, nor have we had any for several weeks, to my knowledge, as I have been all the way down the river in the night, to within four miles of West Point; and also twice in the day time, and I never saw or heard of a picket.
If there is one river in this State easily defended it is the Pamunkey.
In several places the banks are seventy feet perpendicular above the river and a steamer is compelled to go within one hundred and fifty set of these banks.
Whose fault is it that a trade of half a million bushels of grain is not protected?
The Yankees said when they came up that they intended to put a stop to the grain trade.

div3.head: The dash into Moorefield, Va.

opener.dateline: Headq's Jones's Brigade, New Market, Jan. 6, 1863.

div3.p:
I hasten to give you the news from the late expedition to Moorefield.
On the 2d of January a portion of this brigade, with a few pieces of artillery, started from this point, reaching the vicinity of Moorefield about daylight the next morning, having marched about sixty miles. The enemy had at or near the town a camp of infantry and one battery.
The pickets were surprised and a portion of them captured.
An artillery duel then commenced which lasted, with several intervals, till late in the evening.
During this time a detachment of cavalry, under Col. Dulaby, passed around a portion of their force and advanced on Petersburg, which is a beautiful village twelve miles from Moorefield.
When within a half mile of the place he belted for information a short time.
Unfortunately for him the enemy heard of his approach, and taking advantage of this delay set fire to their stores.
The Colonel charged, but too late to get any amount of plunder.
The flames had nearly consumed the building which was a very fine church, and sugar and coffee in small quantities were about all his men obtained from the consecrated ruins.
After paroling the small garrison, with one commissioned officer, they returned to their command.
News of the fight was immediately conveyed to Milroy, thirty-two miles distant, and he reinforced the place with a heavy force of infantry and artillery.

Sixty-five prisoners, with their rifles, were captured, together with six fine horses.
After the enemy had been so strongly reinforced.
General Jones, with his command, returned to camp, with out the loss of a man.

div3.head: General Assembly of Virginia.
div3.p: Senate.--The Senate was called to order at half-past 11 o'clock by Mr. Johnson, of Bedford.

The President laid before the Senate a letter of the Governor of Georgia, accompanied by a resolution of the Georgia Legislature upon the subject of the production of provisions and the partial prohibition of the production of cotton during the war; also, a letter from the Governor of Florida, and a resolution of the Florida Legislature to guarantee, by the States, the debt of the Confederate Government, and a resolution in relation to the present war. The Georgia documents were ordered to be printed and referred to the Committee on Courts of Justice.
The papers from Florida were ordered ty be printed and referred to the Committee on Confederate Relations.

Resolutions of inquiry into expediency were offered: By Mr. Brannon, of imposing a tax on the incomes of extortioners and speculators since the war, whether the same may have been invested or not; by Mr. Bail, of amending the record law, relating to deeds and other writings, so as to enable citizens living in counties whose clerks' offices are closed to dispose of their property by deed; by Mr. Dickinson, of Prince Edward, of refunding fines imposed on persons for distilling brandy from fruit; by Mr. Collier, of referring the Governor's report on the Adjutant-General to Committee on Military Affairs.
A bill to authorize the Governor to organize and offer an occasional force to the Confederate Government was introduced by Mr. Collier with the leave of the Senate.

Mr. Collier offered a joint resolution, which, under the rules, lays over one day, directing the Governor to demand of the Secretary of War passports for members to travel on the State railroads during the present session of the General Assembly, to save the members the trouble of renewing the same.
The Senate adopted a resolution to meet every day at 12 o'clock till otherwise ordered.
On motion of Mr. Taliaferro, adjourned.
House of Delegates.--The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.

The following Senate bills were read first and second times, by their title, and committed: "An set to enlarge the powers of the Common Council of the city of Richmond;" "An act to prescribe the mode of filling vacancies in the General Assembly of Virginia in certain cases;" "An act changing the time of holding elections at the next general election of members of the Legislature" Laid on the table. "a bill in regard to general and special, elections of members of Congress during the present war" Committed.

The Speaker assigned new members to the following committees: Mr. Marye, Finance and Library; Mr. Powell Military Affairs and Finance; Mr. Fry, Course of Justice and Claims; Mr. Fulton, Roads and Navigation, and Lunatic Asylums.

The Chair laid before the House a communication from the Governor, transmitting a letter from the Governor of Georgia, in which was enclosed an act passed by the Legislature of Georgia, on the subject of an increase of the product on of provisions and the restriction of the cultivation of cotton, which was, on the motion of Mr. Bouldin, referred to the Special Committee on the Limitation of the Cultivation of Tobacco.
Also, a communication enclosing resolutions passed by the Legislature of Florida, in relation to the guarantee by that state of her proportion of the Confederate debt, which was referred to an appropriate committee.

Mr. Lynn offered a resolution to instruct the Committee on Finance to inquire into the expediency of relieving the citizens of Prince William county from taxation, and also of providing support for women and children whose husbands and fathers are in the Confederate army, or have been slain in battle.
The resolution was agreed to.

Mr. Bredford, of Clarke, offered a joint resolution that the General Assembly of Virginia request our representatives in Congress to use their efforts to procure the passage of a bill by Congress providing for the payment for slaves impressed into the service or the Confederacy, and not returned to their owners by reason of escaping to, or having been captured by, the public enemy.
Objection being made, the resolution was laid over.
Mr. Magruder submitted a resolution instructing the Military Committee to report a bill providing Prentise for harboring deserters, Agreed to.

Mr. Ambers submitted a resolution, which was agreed to that the Board of Public Works be directed to report to this House in what manner they have performed the duty directed by a joint resolution passed on the 6th of October, 1862. Also, a resolution to inquire into the expediency of repealing the 21st section of the tax bill, passed March 27, 1862, so that Sheriffs and Commissioners of the Revenue may receive the compensation allowed prior to the passage of said act. This resolution was also agreed to.

On motion of Harrison, of London, the resolution submitted by him yesterday in reference to making Confederate Treasury notes a legal tender was taken up and amended so as to read, "that, in the opinion of the General Assembly of Virginia, the Confederate States have the power and should at once make the Treasury notes of the Confederate States a legal fender in payment of debts.

The resolution was discussed at some length by Messrs Harrison, Anderson of Botetourt, and Robertson of Richmond, in its favor, and Messrs Hunter of Jefferson, and Bouldin of Charlotte, in opposition to it. It was finally referred to a special committee of seven, consisting of Messrs Harrison, Hunter, Anderson, Bouldin, Robertson, Forbes and Burkes.
Mr. Marye submitted a resolution that the Committee Finance be instructed to inquire into the expediency of releasing from taxation for the present year the citizens of Fredericksburg — agreed to.
On motion of Mr. Hopkins, of Petersburg the bill on the subject of extortion was taken up, read by its title and referred back to the special committee from which it came.
Chair laid before the House a communication from the Governor in response to a resolution of the House requesting information with reference to the State Line — referred.
Mr. Magruder offered a resolution that, as it Legislature of October, are not properly cared for, the Governor adopt such steps as will accrue greater attention to their comfort.
[A discussion which ensued on this resolution showed that great neglect had prevailed with reference to the food and shelter of these slaves.]

Mr. Anderson, of Rockbridge, offered a resolution that a committee of nine on the part of the House, and five on the part of the Senate, be appointed to consider the expediency of removing, the present session of the General Assembly from the capital.

[On this resolution the vote stood ayes 37, noes 37.
So the motion was not agreed to.]
On motion of Mr. Gazenova, the House adjourned.

div3.head: Execution of a Woman for murder.
div3.p:
--The sentence of the Hustings Court of Richmond, condemning Margaret, slave of Mrs. Mary M. Butt, of Oxford, North Carolina, to death, for the murder of Francis Deans Tardy, infant child of Mr. Samuel C. Tardy, on the 3d day of December last, was duly carried into effect yesterday at ten minutes past twelve o'clock, on an elevated plateau on the side of the hill east of the new City Almahouse and Powder Magazine, in the immediate vicinity of the spot where Louis Napoleon alias John Richardson was executed for counterfeiting Confederate Treasury notes.
The procession escorting the prisoner to the scaffold consisted of a guard from the City Battalion, surrounding the wagon which contained the condemned, sitting on her coffin, and the jailor, following which was the carriage of Lt. Dove, City Physician, and other vehicles.--On the sidewalk, following the cortege, were promiscuously mingled civilians, soldiers, and negroes by hundreds all pushing forward with a determination that be spoke their intent to be present at the execution.
The procession started from the jail at twenty minutes past eleven o'clock, and proceeded immediately to 17th street, the most direct road to the place of execution.
Up to the hour of starting the condemned was engaged in devotional exercises — a portion of the time with Rev. Mr. Watkins, pastor of the Second Baptist (African) Church, and afterwards with Rev. L. W. Sesley, so both of whom she had uniformly protested her innocence.
When the time arrived for starting she came out of the jail smiling and at the best humor possible.
Tripping lightly down the steps leading into the jail yard, she adieu to the old colored cook in a voice in no wise broken by emotion, and emerging from the gate into the street, bowed to all she knew.--Nearly a half hour was consumed in the journey from the jail to the gallows, and during the whole time she preserved a very calm demeanor.
A brief interval of time elapsed before she the staffold, which was occupied by her in conversation with several persons who approached her. She persisted in the assertion that she was innocent, and willing to die. The time arriving for her execution she ascended the steps leading to the platform without help.
The Sergeant then proceeded to read the record of the Court condemning her, to which she listened with marked attention.
This duty does she was told she could say anything she pleased.
She commenced and continued at some length, in a perfectly free and unembarrassed manner in a clear voice and perfectly distinct enunciation, and without any of those contortions of the body in which persons of her class in the same situation are apt. to indulge.
She said she was sorry that the Governor had not allowed her time, in order that her mother might see her — She said though innocent she trusted her fate might serve as a warning to both white and black, who had assembled to see her die. She was prepared to go; and though the mode was horrible, she trusted when the pain of the body was over her spirit would rest in Heaven, &c. Her address ended, a brief interlude occurred, when she again a coke, to the same purport, however, as on the first occasion Rev. Mr. Sesley, who was on the scaffold with the girl, then, at her request, read the following address, which she had composed for the occasion:

q.p:
My Dear Friends You have assembled here to see me a poor criminal hung I are glad to see you that I can tell one and all I know I die a painful death but thanks be to God I die perfectly innocent My sufferings in this wicked and slat till world will soon be over, Those that have condemned me I willingly forgive though they gave me but a short time to prepare myself for this bearable death.
My Lord Jesus as said in His Holy Word that we must for give in hopes to be forgiven, I have prayed to my God trusting in Him as my Redeemer.
If there is any of my friends pleasant I take it hard of them that they did not send me a few clean clothes for the last time, but I forgive them hoping God may, I never though I would come to this, I never was accused of anything wrong before any of you that are pleasant can go to Mr. Pocahontas Butt and enquire my character.
There is only one thing.
I are sorry to leave this world for, and that is my poor Mother I should liked to of seen my dear Mother once more but it is not granted to me so I must leave her in the Hans if God hoping she may walk in His way's so that the may meet me some day at the throne of God, where there is no sorrow or pain no trouble but all joy world without end, I have thought hard of it when two of Mrs Tardy's family died the same way and I poor creature like me to be accused of it but I forgive in hopes of being forgiven I wish you all farewell take me as a warning and prepare to meet me in Heaven, I hope some of my friends will publish this letter in the Dispatch, so the world may see I die prepared and happy.
Margaret Ang Hutter

div3.p:
The reading of this paper was followed by an address and prayer by Rev. Mr. Seeley During the latter she exhibited the first signs of emotion noticeable.
She shed a few tears.
The prayer concluded, she embraced the opportunity to make another address.
In this letter she said that had the woman who bore testimony against her before the Court been allowed to proceed and tell all she knew, she (the witness), would have shown her innocence, and now occupy the place she did on the gallows.
She said no more on this point, but bid all present farewell.
Kershands were then pinioned by the jailor, the rope (a cotton cord) affixed to her neck, the black cap drawn over her face, and the jailor and preacher left the scaffold.
A moment after a heavy thud against the side of the scaffold announced to the thousands assembled that the fatal drop had fallen.
As usual on such occasions, an audible murmur from the crowd was heard to break the silliness that reigned around.--The body gyrated till the coils of the rope unwound.
A spasmodic contraction of the shoulders and a few struggles, and the body motioniest.
After being suspended for eighteen minutes the cords that confined her hands were unloosed, and Dr. Dove pronounced her dead.
The body was then lowered and given in charge of the undertaker, who proceeded to bury it in the colored burying ground, not far from the place of execution.
We learn that two days before the execution Governor Letcher was applied to for a respite, and announced his willingness to grant it if it were needed to prepare her for death.
He was told that, in the opinion of those asking the favor, she would never be any better prepared than she was then.
The respite was declined.
We greatly doubt whether an exhibition of the kind is either instructive or . It is certainly horrible to look at especially when the victim is a women.
We truce that the next execution will take place in the jail yard.
The party who suffered yesterday was a bright mulatto, of medium size, aged twenty years and unusually intelligent for one of her class.
If guilty of the crime for which she suffered she died with a lie on her lips and with consummate art the part of a self-possessed and innocent person.

div3.head: Another Abolition Exodus.
div3.p:
--In addition to the five hundred abolition soldiers sent to City Point Yesterday morning, the same number will be started in that direction this morning, in charge of Dr. V. , flag officer.
This will leave on hand sixty-nine unadulterated Abolition soldiers, and twenty-five officers six of whom are in the hospital wounded.
Most of the soldiers who remain are in such a condition that will preclude their removal for some time.
There were yesterday in the Lit by prison, besides the above 210 citizens, 117 deserters from the Yankee army and 33 negroes.
Under the provisions of President Davis's last proclamation none of the yankee officers are to be sent home until the scoundrels of some of Lincoln's is atoned for.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p: --The following deserters were lodged in Castle Thunder yesterday, viz: Thos Conner, co F, 6th Ls; John Thompson battery No. 4; Peter Reynolds, co E. Walker's Guard; John Connor, battery No. 4; Wm King, co. L 1st S C; John Riley, alias Rowe, alias Moore, co E, 18th Va; Martin Tierney, co O, 19th Miss; J W Rearden, co D, battery No. 4; Serg's Mansfield, co C, 14th Ls; Mike Flinn do, false papers and resisting the guard; F W Garrison, co D, 46th Va; Richard Buckhead, do, deserters.
The two men, E D Fish and G Nellis, arrested by order of Gen Wise, on the charged of attempting to get to the enemy in New Kent, were discharged yesterday by order of Gen Winder.

div3.head: Disposed of.
div3.p: --The negro fellow who, not long since, made a murderous attack our and mained for life, Mr. Samuel Hall, Superintendent of Henrico County Poor House, and who was apprehended by our pickets on the south side of James river, while trying to make his way to the enemy, brought to Richmond, tried before Henrico County Court, and sentenced to be hung on Friday, January 2d, for the offence, was duly executed on the day appointed, by the Sheriff, in the yard of the old jail, in presence of a number of spectators.

div3.head: Arrests.
div3.p:
--Yesterday officers Perrin and Grone, of the day police, arrested and caged J H Goodman and C Goodman, on the charge of stealing a pair of blankets, worth $30 from C W Spicer.
They will be brought before the Mayor this morning.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p:
Mayor's Court.--There were but few cases before the Mayor yesterday, and these few hardly deserve mention.
George, a slave, owned by Mr James Johnson, was arraigned for having in his possession one piece of meal, supposed to Lave been stolen.
He failed to show his right to its possession and was awarded a licking.
Wm A King, a soldier, found in a door-way Thursday night in a decided state of intoxication, was sent to the Provost Marshal.
To day is set apart for the examination of Michael Sarry, who is charged with being concerned in the garroting and robbing of Lieutenant Warren S Story, of Georgia, on Cary street, a few weeks since.

Henrico County Court.--The only case before the Justices of Henrico county yesterday was that of Israel, slave of John R. Allen, charged with stealing a hog. The offense was proved and the defendant ordered 99 inches, which were immediately administered to the culprit by the Sheriff in the yard adjoining the Scarfell use.

div3.head:
Latest from New Orleans.
Brilliant naval Exploit.
the "Harriet Lane" captured!
another steamer Slown up with all on Board.
div3.p: --A special dispatch, dated Jackson to-day, says the New Orleans Delta, of the 6th, received at Ponchtonia, contains the following:

q.p:
About 2 o'clock on New Year's morning, four rebel gunboats came down Buffalo Bayon into Galveston Bay, and ran alongside the steamer Harriet Lane, one on each side.
The Texan sharp-shooters then commenced an assault on her, and soon succeeded in killing all the gunners and Capt. Wagnewyth, her commander.
The assailants then boarded her, and after a desperate struggle, captured the vessel.
The rebel gunboats were lined and fortified with cotton bales, after the manner of the boats in New Orleans known as the Montgomery fleet.

The Westfield, under Commander Renshaw, determined not to be taken, and, after a consultation, officers and men all agreeing, they blew her up, with all on board, including the commander.
Only eight escaped.

The balance of the Yankee fleet, and one transport, escaped.
Two coal boats at the wharf, with two companies of the 42d Massachusetts Regiment, were captured.
A Federal vessel was pinched to reconnoitre around the harbor to watch the Harriet Lane and prevent the Confederates sending her to sea.

div4.head: Official account of the Affair.
div4.p:
The following official dispatch from Major-Gen. Magruder was received at the War Department yesterday.
It came via Natchez:

div5.head: Headq'rs Galveston, Texas.
div5.p:
This morning, the 1st January, at 3 o'clock, I attacked the enemy's fleet and garrison at this place, and captured the latter and the steamer Harriet Lane, and two barges, and a schooner of the former.
The rest, some four or five, escaped ignominiously under cover of a flag of truce.
I have about six hundred prisoners and a large quantity of valuable stores arms, etc. The Harriet Lane is very little injured.
She was carried by boarding from two high-pressure cotton steamers, manned by Texas cavalry and artillery.
The line troops were gallantly commanded by Colonel Green, of Sibley's brigade, and the ships and artillery by Maj Leon Smith, to whose imitable energy and heroic daring the country is indebted for the successful execution of a plan which I had considered for the destruction of the enemy's fleet--Col. Bagby, of Sibley's brigade, also commanded the volunteers from his regiment for the naval expedition, in which every officer and every man won for himself imperishable renown.

div3.head: Later from the United States.
div3.p:
--The National Intelligencer is the only paper of the 7th received by flag of truce at City Point to-night.
It contains but little news.
Rosecrans telegraphs to Halleck, under date of Jan. 5, that they have fought one of the greatest battles of the war, and that the victory was complete.
Success on the 31st was prevented by the surprise of his right flank — nevertheless, we have beaten the enemy after three days battle.
A dispatch from Nashville says that Stanley's brigade entered Murfreesboro' on Sunday morning. "Our forces were terribly scattered, and out of 136 Colonels engaged 19 were killed.

The Philadelphia Frees has a Nashville dispatch, dated the 5th, which says: "Col. Bruce captured Clarksville, Ten., with a number of prisoners and 80,000 barrels of flour.
The Cumberland is rising rapidly."
Between five and six hundred women and children (refugees) came up on the flag of truce boat, and are now in Petersburg.

div3.head: Still Later from the North--Gov'r Seymour's message to the New York Legislature.
div3.p: --Reports from the other side of the river state that the main body of the enemy is retiring towards Washington.

Gov. Seymour's message to the New York Legislature is published in the Herald of the 8th.
He says that the war has taken more than 200,000 men from the workshops and fields.
There must be no attempt to put down public opinion.
The people demand free discussion, and desire to learn their actual condition.
He says that slavery has been the subject and not the cause of the war. We must look for the cause of the war in the prevailing disregard of the laws and Constitution above all, in local prejudices grown up in the two extremes of the country, where remote positions and interests made them less informed regarding the condition and character of the white people than in the Central and Western States.
Our difficulties teach us that we must reform the people and the policy of the Government.
He says that the rights of the States must be respected.

A consolidated Government in this vast country would destroy the essential rights and liberties of the people.
The sovereignties of States cannot be given up. He denounces arbitrary arrests, the suppression of journals, and the spy system of the General Government, and denies that the rebellion can suspend a single right of the citizens of the loyal States.
He enjoins sheriffs and civil officers to take care that no person is imprisoned or carried from the State by force without process and authority of law. He denounces marital law as opposed to the Constitution and genius of the Government.
The President held his office not by the will of the majority, but by the Constitution, which placed him in office by the vote of 1,800,000 against 2,800,000. If the Constitution cannot keep the Executive within its restraints, he cannot retain the States in the Union. Those who bold that there is no sanctity in the Constitution must admit that there is no guilt in the rebellion.

These practices were more dangerous to our liberties than the rebellion itself!
He condemns the emancipation proclamation as impolitic, unjust, and unconstitutional, they may be construed as the abandonment of the hope of restoring the Union.--If the South must be held under military subjection, and the negroes be managed by the Government the Government must be converted into a military despotism.
The opinion that the South must be subjugated has weakened the hopes of the people and destroyed confidence abroad.

The message argues that the Union is indissoluble, and that factions North and South must be put down.
So closely, he says, are the Upper and Lower Valleys of the Mississippi bound together that when cotton was burned in Louisiana corn was used as fuel in Illinois.
It ruins the Southern consumer and bankrupts the Northern producer.--Neither in a Northern nor Southern Union can the conflicting interests of agriculture, commerce, and manufactures be adjusted.

Dispatches from Cairo, dated the 7th, say that Sherman fought his way within two miles of Vicksburg.
The fighting was desperate in the extreme-Regiments and brigades fought hand to hand.
The 4th Iowa lost 600. Gen. Hovey, with 15,000 men, sent on a special mission, is missing.
Gen. Holme is marching in the direction of Vicksburg.
The rebel force at Vicksburg is over 65,000, and their entrenchments extend six miles from the city.

Sherman was attacked on the 29th and driven back to the first line of his defences, after taking the main battery and rifle pits.
The loss is estimated at from four to five thousand.
Grant, who is at Holly Springs, did not reinforce Sherman.
The Federal General Again was killed; General Morgan L. Smith was wounded.
Farragut and Porter were expected to co-operate with Sherman and McClernand.
Banks's army was divided into two columns and sent on an independent expedition.

Butler, in a speech at Philadelphia on the 7th, attempted to justify the murder of Mumford, and said that, rightly or uprightly, the act commended.
Itself to his judgment.
The Herald says it is probable that Butler will return to New Orleans, and Banks will push forward in the field.
Butler was to have a public reception in New York on the 8th.

A bill has been passed by Congress providing for the base of $10,000,000 thirty year bonds in aid of emancipation in Missouri, the Government pledging the removal and colonization of the freed slaves.
The Key West correspondent of the Herald learns that the Anglo-rebel steamer Comet, with a valuable

div3.head: Movements of Bragg's army.
div3.p: --The advertiser and Register has the following private dispatch, dated Dechard, Tenn., January 7th:

div4.p:
Being outnumbered more than two to one by the enemy, and our troops utterly exhausted by the cold and rain and four days incessant fighting, with loss in killed and wounded, Gen. Bragg determined to fail back to Duck river.
The enemy showed he was receiving large reinforcements from Kentucky.

By a skillful night march, covered by the admirable cavalry of Wheeler and Wharton, the whole army, with all its supplies and captured arms, is now concentrating in its new lines, and ready for the enemy whenever he shall advances.
Since this army crossed the Tennessee river in November we have captured 9,500 prisoners, over 40 pieces of artillery, 8,000 small arms, and lots of wagons.

div3.head: Advance of Rosecrans's army--Yankee outrages.
div3.p: --The enemy has advanced his lines seven miles this side of Murfreesboro'. He has been guilty of the most outrageous enormities, stealing private property, robbing peaceful citizens, and running off negroes.

div3.head: Refusal of the Yankees to receive their prisoners
div3.p:
--The Atlanta Intelligencer says that the Yankee prisoners taken at Murfreesboro' were returned to the Yankee authorities who refused to receive them unless accompanied by the officers.
Seventy-three Yankee officers are in Atlanta.

div3.head: From North Carolina.
div3.p:
--The State Journal has reliable information from Newbern that the enemy, not less than 80,000 strong, are on the cost, and a most formidable fleet at Beaufort.
It is supposed that an attack is meditated on Wilmington and Goldsboro'.

div3.head:
[Southern Association Dispatches.]
Rosecrans Reported Retreating — Bragg's position.
div3.p: --There is a rumor to-day that Rosecrans army has retreated to Nashville, leaving a small garrison at Murfreesboro'.

Gen. Bragg's headquarters are at Winchester.
He will make his line of defence between Winchester and Shelbyville.
It is probable that the Abolition army will not be ready for offensive operations under a month.
Our expeditious in West Tennessee and Kentucky have been most successful, and will bring good fruits.

Our troops, as a general thing, approve General Braggs course in falling back.
His troops were too much exhausted to remain longer in the field.

div3.head: Northern intelligence.
div3.p: --The flag of truce boat arrived at City Point to-day, bringing over five hundred women and children.
The Baltimore Gazette, of the 7th instant, has been received.
The Gazette has intelligence that Banks has released all political prisoners at New Orleans, including Mayor Monroe.
General Grant telegraphs to Halleck that Sherman captured Vicksburg on the 3d.
Havana dates to the 28th ultimo have been received.
Concha [Captain-General of Cubs, we believe,--Reporter.] has resigned.
A Spanish embassy on the Mexican question is the subject of general debate in the Mexican Senate.

Don Calderon Celania has approved the re-embarkation of Gen. Prim's forces.
He says the allies ought not to interfere in the affairs of Mexico, because when making overtures to the United States to participate no such intention was expressed.
Rosecrans's army now occupies Murfreesboro' and will probably winter there.

div4.p: In this city, on Thursday evening 8th instant, at the residence of Mr. J. F. Mayo, by the Rev. J. T. Wallace Mr. John Driver, of Wake county, North Carolina, to Miss Theresa Bradley, of Caroline county, Va.

On the 8th instant, by the Rev. Philip Price, R. P. McGURRE.
of Alabama, to Miss N. E. Chappell, of this city.
In this city, on the 9th inst, at the residence of her mother, of typhoid fever, Mary J., daughter of Johannah and the late John Sexton, formerly of Baltimore, aged 14 years.

lg.l: Gone to sleep with the tender smile frozen on her slender lips.
By the farewell kiss of her dewy breath;
Gold in the clasp of the angel Death,
Like the lest bud of a fading wreath,
Whose bloom the white frost nips.

div4.p: Her funeral will take place from, St. Peter's Cathedral on Sunday, the 11th instant, at 3 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend.
On yesterday, the 9th, in the 4th year of her age, Kate James, only child of Lanreston S. and Sallie A. Moore.
The funeral ceremony will take place from Grace Street Baptist (Dr. Jeter's) Church this morning at 11 o'clock. The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend.
In Manchester of scarlet fever, on Thursday, the 8th inst, Charlotte Brooks, youngest daughter of Benjamin S. and Catharms Stocks, aged 2 years 4 months and 5 days.

Little Charlotte is gone; yes, she has gone from a world of suffering and care to a fairer and brighter world on high; and though a stricken mother weeps when she gazes on the cold and lifeless form and thinks of all her winning ways, there is in her heart a deep and unutterable joy in the thought that her little spirit is freed from all its sufferings, and has gone to join the angles in Heaven.
Oh! Charlotte, thrice, blessed babe, we almost envy thy peaceful rest on the bosom of our Saviour, who has so gracefully said. "Suffer little children to come unto me, and forbid them not; for of such is the kingdom of Heaven."

div4.head: Funeral notice.
div4.p:
--The funeral sermon of the late Richard Wilmer Weisiger will be preached at St. James's Church to-morrow (Sunday) morning, at the usual hour.
His friends are invited to attend.

div3.head: Capture of Yankees and horses.
div3.p:
On Monday last Captain John H. McVelli, of Ranger, made a dash upon the Yankees in Hardy county and succeeded in killing one, and in capturing 33 man, 61 hores, 9 sets of caddies, and bridles, 14 revolvers, 14 Burnside rifles, and 20 rabies.
This was accomplished after the Confederate forces, under General Jones, retired from the county.
The party under Mr. Neill consisted of 50 men. They also captured several waggons, which, in their hasts to retire, on account of the nearness of the enemy, they act fire to.

div3.head: Eastern North Carolina.
div3.p: Our Raleigh exchanges state that there were in the House river, near Newbern, on Wednesday last, no less than fifty three Yankee transports.--The forces at that point include the commands of three Major General usually, in the Yankee army 15,000 each, which gives the full force at 45,000 to 50,000 men. This intelligence is regarded as reliable.

div3.head: From the Valley.
div3.p:
A gentleman who arrived in this city yesterday evening from the Valley informs us that a body to Yankee cavalry came up the Valley as far as Woods stock on Wednesday On Saturday last the were at Batersburg, where they remained until Sunday, levying contributions upon the citizens of bacon flour earn and other supplies, and of those who had nothing of the kind they demanded money.
The contribution were obligated at the point the bayonet and the citizens were compelled a submit not only to the levy, but to every species of insult and modernity which the mercenary choose to keep upon them.

Geo. W. Doswell
Sale by Dickinson & Hill, Auctioneers. ja 8--tds

div3.p: I will Sell, at the Auction Rooms of Hill Dickinson & Co, on the 12th of January, 1863 one Woman (Mary) and child, to the highest bidder, for cash, as Commissioner of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond.

div3.head: Free Negroes for Sale at Auctions.
div3.p:
In pursuance of an order of the Hustings Court of the city of Richmond made at December term of said Court, I will sell on Monday, the 11th day of January, 1861.
(that being Court 1y,) in front of the City Hall, to the highest bidder, for cash, the following Free Negroes, convicted of grand 1cony, and ordered to be sold into absolute slavery, viz: Bara Edmondson, Edward Petterson, and Nathan Drayton.
Sale at 10½ o'clock A. M.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of real estate, ten Negroes, and other personal property, at Auction.
div3.p: --As administrator of one Fund, dec'd, I shall proceed to sell upon the premises, on Monday, the 12th day of January, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., in the following order, the valuable real estate and personal property, to wit:

list.item:
1st.
The tract of land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run turnpike, in Henrico, about 8 miles West of the city of Richmond.
It contains about 63 acres of land, well improved.--The improvements consist of a comfortable dwelling with two rooms, barn, stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest fruit trees.

2d.
Another small tract, containing 4½ acres of land, near to the above.

3d.
A tract of land on the Deep Run turnpike, 6 miles from the city, on which there is a comfortable dwelling, containing four good rooms, and the usual out-houses.
This tract will be sold at 2½ P. M.

div3.p: After the sale of the first named tract (any commencing at 12 o'clock M.,) will be sold ten likely Negroes, consisting men, boys, women and children.
Also, a large lot of Household and Kitchen Furniture.

Terms--For the real estate, one-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes with interest added, and secured by trust deeds; if desired, the whole purchase money will be received.
For the slaves and other personal property, cash will be required.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico county, and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts. de 30
