div3.head: Resistance of paper of shot.
div3.p:
--Experiments recently made in England prove that paper pasteboard better resists shot from cannon than hard teak wood.
Two targets were constructed with one inch plate iron — the one backed by fourteen inches in thickness of teak wood, the other backed by the same thickness of pasteboard.
They were fired at with a whitworth 6 pounder, using elongated shot 5½ inches in length and 2½ in diameter, and the penetration was found to be twice as great in the timber backed forget that it was in the paper one.
The targets were then fired at with a 12-pounder, and with like results.
The resistance of pasteboard to shot has attracted so much attention on the other side of the Atlantic that further experiments are to be made with it.

div3.head: An Exhumed City.
div3.p:
--A most singular discovery has been made on the French coast, near the month of the Garenue.
A town has been discovered, buried in the sand, and a church has already been extracted from the sand.
Its original plan shows it to have been built towards the close of the Roman Empire, but changes made in it had given it the appearance of an edifice of mixed style, in which the Gothic architecture has usurped the place of the Roman.
Its original paintings, its admirable sculptured choir, and Roman capitals, are adorned with profuse ornaments, which are attracting numbers of visitors.
This temple is all that remains of those cities described by Pliny and Strabo.
The Gulf of Gascony abounds in guns of these ancient cities, It has been 1,500 years since Novigamus, the old capital of Medoe, which masters of Gaul, was buried under the ocean.
Of all that tract of territory, the Roche du Cordonan alone is visible.
The remains of Roman roads, The site of Jupiter's temple, the vestiges of the Spanish Moors, and the road Elenore de Guyenne, have been rescued from the sands in the neighborhood of the long buried city of Soulas.--Now here have the erosions of the ocean been greater than on the coast of Gascony.

div3.head:
iron Works,
Richmond, Nov. 28, 1862.
div3.p: Wanted--five hundred hands.--We wish to hire for the ensuing year five hundred able-bodied negro men, to be employed by us at our in Botetourt county, and at our Coal Mines, on James river, seventeen miles above this city.
An our works generally are remote from the enemy's lines, and the negroes are well guarded, we think it greatly for the interest of those having hands to dispose of to hire them to us.
The negroes will be supplied with the very best provisions, which have already been secured, and good clothing provided for them at all seasons of the year.

Those of whom we have hands hired for the present year will please inform us whether we shall return those hands at the furnishes until they are re-hired; and if not, to what point they shall be returned, as some of the owners may have changed their places of residence.
Payments for the hire of these hands will be made either at Farmville, Lynchburg, Fincastle, or this city, annually or quarterly, at the option of the owner.

Applications can be made to F. T. Glasgow, Fincastle; Wm. T. Putton, at Clover Dale Furnace; James L. Patton, at Grace Furnace; Wm. Jordan, Alum Spring; John H. Jamieson, Lynchburg; Benjamin Holladay, Frederick's Hall, Louisa co.; James M. Poindexter, Farmville, or the undersigned, at these works.

div3.head: Wanted — Laborers.
div3.p:
--I wish to hire for the James River and Kanawha Company, a large force of negro Carpenters and Laborers, to work on the repairs of the Canal between this city and Lynchburg during the ensuing year.
The company will give similar wages to what other companies in the State may pay, and will feed, clothe, and pay all doctor's bills.
For any further information address the undersigned here; Magers.
Gray & Anderson at Lynchburg, or any one of the master mechanics or overseers located on the first division of the Canal.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--The undersigned wished to employ in his own family, for the year 1863, a first-rate Seamstress and House Servant.
As a seamstress, she must know how to cut and fit children's clothes and bodies' dresses, and come well recommended, (white preferred). Apply to me, at the Telegraph Office; , in my absence, at my residence on Franklin street, first door from 9th st., left hand side.

div3.head:
Office R. F. & P. R. R. Co.,
Richmond, dec. 29, 1862.
div3.p:

Also, eighty colored hands, to work on repairs of road.
Apply to

div3.p:

Also, good Carpenters and Smiths, and a few men to work at the Coke yards in this city.--Abundant provisions and good clothing will be furnished.

Apply to P. V. Daniel, Jr., 8th street. Also, a female Cook, Washer, and Ironer, and two Maid Servants.
Apply to , or to T. C. Daniel, Marshall street, above 1st.

div3.head: Lost negro man found.
div3.p:
--Davy, a tall black, negro man, with short whickers and moustache, and clothed in homespun about hall worn, was delivered to me for safekeeping by Conductor W. H. Taylor last Saturday week.--Davy says he belongs to Joe Wright of Pittsylvania county, about 30 miles from Danville, and was on his way to wall on his young master, who is a Lieutenant in Ge. Wise's Brigade.
The owner will please come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take his servant.
Apply to

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--From the G. R. Shops, Haches Quarter Branch, Richmond, Va, on Tuesday, the 6th inst a negro man, named William, in blacksmith by trade, Said negro was purchased in warren county, N. G. from the estate of Poler Powell, & Gwin, or Mr. Dupres, and brought to Richmond and resold to Hatcher & Washer.
Said negro is about five feet ten inches high, copper complexion, with a pleasing countenance.
He had on when he left a gray missed suit of clothes and gray can. He has a of his less the one not remember because by a a mule.
It is supposed bereft with General Reasm's division, as it passed through on that day, perhaps having met with some acquaintance and told a plausible late.
I will pay a reward of $25 for said negro if arrested State of Virginia; or $100 it miles out of the State, and confined in any jail, so that he can be pound; or delivered to Hill, Dickinson &Co. Auct s, or to the undersigned

closer.signed: Sup't C. S. Lots, Bacon's Quarrier Branch,
Enquirer and Examiner cony Hill supped.

div3.head: Two hundred Dollars Reward
div3.p:
--For the apprehension and delivery in Richmond, Va., of a negro man named Reward.
Said buy was lost near Winchester about the first day of last October while the Richmond Howitzers were marching from Martinsburg Rewards Bunker Hill At the time of his he was cooking for one of his young masters, (Miles H. Gardner) of the 3d Howitzer Company.
He is supposed to be cooking or waiting in some regiment at corner Winchester.

description.--Edward is about 18 or 19 years of age, stent and compact in form, 5 feet 6 or 8 inches in height black, smooth skin, a full head of hair, and rather pleasing in appearance when spoken to dresses well, and wears an air of dignity to kin race.

The above reward will be pain upon his delivery to my Building.
Franklin street corner of 16th.
For further particulars address the subscriber, at Richmond, Va.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the Exchange Stables, (late Davis & Hutcheson's) on Sunday morning last, the 4th instant, a negro man named Tom. Tom is a short man; about five feet three or four inches high; pale yellow color; dark sandy hair, rather bushy; right moustache and whiskers; square made; a little knowledge, and has a determined, vicious countenance.
He had on when be left a white slouched hat and light pantaloons.
He sometimes wore a blue shirt, with along neck-handkerchief and a soldier's blue overcoat, with cope.
He had with him a Bondie containing two blankets, a new black sack coat, and other clothing.
I will give the above reward of $100 for his delivery to me at my stables, or secured in any jail in Richmond, that I may get him again.
Tom was recently purchased of Col. of Charles City county.
He may be ted somewhere in the city but it is most likely he will make his way to Charles City and the Yankees lines.
if taken out of the city, and conveyed to me, I will give $200 reward for him.

div3.head: Seventy-five Dollars Reward
div3.p:
-- I will give for the apprehension and commitment to jail, so that I get them of negroes Pompey, Jim, and William Henry, or $25 for each, who ran off — Pompey and william Henry on the 27th, and Him on the 30th or December, 1863.
These negroes I removed from Williamsburg (my residence) in May last, and doubtless they are aiming, through Petersburg and Richmond, to reach the Yankee lines in that vicinity, or to pass over James river below Petersburg.

Jim is a tawney cotton, about 20 years old, and Pompey a shade darker, 18 years old, likely, tail, and well grown, each were a cavalry uniform cap and each had on wooden bottom shoes, and plated.
jim head on a pair of blue homespun pants, and Pompey a blue Yankee coat, and he has lately had one of his finger of the right hand) bruited or mashed.
William Henry a likely fed, about 14 years old, and of town.
color, is doubtless with Pompey.
div3.closer:
Robert. H. Armistead,
Forkland Nottoway co. Va. ja 2--3t*

div3.head: Two hundred Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway in the month of August. 1861, my negro women Liza, sometimes called Elizabeth Gibbs, half white, hair inclined to court, large Black eyes, tall and straight, a small spot on one side of her face, does not speak very quick when spoken to about 28 or 30 year old; was formerly owned and sold by Mr. Lipscomb living near Broad Beck., in the county of Chesterfield.
She may be lurking about in that vicinity, or the town of Manchester, or the city of Richmond, about which places she is well acquainted.
The above reward of $200 will he paid for her delivery tome at Public Warehouse, of secured in any jail so that I get her again.
div3.closer:
B. J. Vaughan.
Richmond, Jan. 8th, 1863. ja 8--2aw4w*

div3.p:
Fifty Dollars Reward will be paid for my bright mulatto girl Ellen/ She has a face and chin; blue eyes, long.
straight hair.
and large feet, she in 5 feet 2 inches high.
She had on when she left a faded yellow calico dress, a Virginia cloth apron wish a body and long sleeves.
She will try to pass for free, or davis some means to delve any one who tried to arrest her. She has been seen several times in the neighborhood of 17th street, and Union Hill and Church on Church Hill.
I will give the above reward for her arrest and if harbored by any one and it can be proved, I will give 325 more on conviction.
div3.closer:
L. Powers,
Corner Venable and 17th sts. ja 7--3t*

div3.head: Reward
div3.p:
--The subscriber will pay a reward of $50 for his negro boy Simon, who was hired out in Richmond to My R. G. Hown by Wm S. Phillips in the year 1862.
The said boy has run away.
He is about 16 or 17 years of ago, is well grown, of a color a little yellow, is a smart, intelligent boy; has been a plow boy, and can wait in a house very well; he was rased near Bruington Church.
King and Queen county, Va. I will pay the above reward for the delivery of Simon to Mr. Wm. S. Phillipe, in Richmond; or the subscriber, in King and Queen county.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--My Savant Boy. John Simmons, in September last, arrived at or near Winchester, Va., on the way from Port Gibson, Miss, to the camps of my company.
He failed to find the camp, and may be in the employment of some person in the army, or may be in jail.
I will pay she above reward to any one who will deliver him at Mr. T. A. Bulkley's store, on Main street, Richmond.
Said John is about 23 years old, a very bright mulatto has an impediment in his speech rather long, waving heir, and looks younger than he is.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars Reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, near the Hanover Junction, on Christian day, a negro man named Jal. He is very stout and healthy, about 5 feet 10 or 11 inches high, about 25 years old, of a light black complexion, and speaks quick.
The above reward will he paid to any one who with deliver him to me or place him in the Hanover county.
div3.closer:
Chad. Y. M. Garnett.
Hanover Junction, Jan. 3.1863. ja 5--8t*

div3.head: One hundred Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the persons who hired them, two Women, having each a child with them, about three or four years old. One of the women, named Maria is about twenty years old, of brown color and is about and-very likely; heritages when spoken to and has a small scar on one of her cheeks; he child has a sour on one of its ankles, The other woman is named Susan.
She has been injured in one of her hips and limps badly, is of brown color, and is about twenty three years old. Her is of darker color than she is. They have releases in Richmond and Manchester, in one of which places they may be lurking.
I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of I women with their children or fifty dollars for corner to the per Groton "Lyne, corner of Well and Franklin street, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Fifty Dollar Reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, about the 1st at November last, my negro man Charles.
The above reward will be paid to any one who will deliver him to me on my plantation in Halifax county, near Barksdale's Depot, on the Richmond and Danville railroad, or Austine Hime in some county jail so that I can get him. He is about 5 feet 11 inches high, ginger-bread color; usually wears his hair plaited, an when not planted has a full head of hair He was bought recently, Va, and it is believed he is making his way to his old neighborhood.
May post office in Whitieck, Halifax, Va.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away on the 2d Jan. 1863, from Jordan Cox's Chesterfield county, Va., boy Sam; dark gingercake color.
about 5 feet fail, with a soar in the right temple, mullet mouth, two broad teeth in front, and full eyes.
The above reward will be paid for his confinement in any place so that I can get hold of him. Address.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber about the 1st of October, a negro boy named Robert, about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high; of a dark ginger bread color; had a sulky appearance, and had on when he left a full suit of Yankee clothes.
The above reward will be paid upon the receipt of his delivery in any jail in Richmond.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away about one mouth ago, a negro man, belonging to Mr, H. M. Ware, named Albert.
Said negro is about 6 feet 9 of 10 inches high, of ginger bread color, thin Vienna, somewhat abrupt in his answers; is front teeth decayed, and dresses well field fellow was hired to Mr, Worsham last year and to Mr. J. P. Billiard for a portion of this year, and no doubt has hired himself to me of the sating or sporting house in this city.
We will give the above reward of $20 for the apprehension and delivery of said negro to us or confined in jail so that we get him again.

John was hired from Mr. H. H. Hoomes, of Fredericksburg.

div3.p: all the members of "Manchester Artillery" having been assigned to me for duty, and there now being quite a number of them absent improperly, all such absentees are ordered to report to me within ten days of this date, at the Camp of Trimble's Brigade, Ewell's Division, near Port Royal Va. Said Bouner deserted, money with him a horse, saddle, and bridle, besides money and valuable papers.
He is about 26 years of age, 5 feet 5 inches in height, dark hair and eyes.
The middle finger of his left hand has been sheaf off.

div3.head: Notice to conscripts of New Ken Charles City, and James of counties,

div4.p: --All persons in the counties of recent, Charles City, and James City, between ages of eighteen and forty years, whether any other portion of the state or of other State are hereby required to report themselves to Enrolling Offices and Examining Board for nation and on the days lived in that next notice of the Examining Board.

div4.p: The undersigned, one of the Examining for the Third Congressional district, under General Orders 82, Adjutant and the pectus General's office hereby gives notice to all whom it may Conders that he has fixed upon the 13th, 14th, and 15th day, of January for the examination of conscripts who shall assemble at Now Kent Court House, from the 20th, 21st, and 22d of January for the examination of conscripts who shall assemble at Charles-City Court-House, for the county of Charles City, in pursuance of the notice from the commandant of conscripts.
